book.name: Hosea
book.info: A period of about sixty years, from approximately 785 B.C., during the reign of Uzziah (Azariah), king of Judah, to approximately 725 B.C., during the reign of Hezekiah, king of Judah ([link]1:1[/link]).
book.subject: Jehovah as Salvation to the Adulterous and Apostate Israel in Receiving Her Back and Restoring Her

verse.text: [note]1[/note]The word of Jehovah which came to [note]2[/note]Hosea the son of Beeri in the days of [xref]a[/xref]Uzziah, [xref]b[/xref]Jotham, [xref]c[/xref]Ahaz, [i]and[/i] [xref]d[/xref]Hezekiah, kings of Judah, and in the days of [xref]e[/xref]Jeroboam the son of Joash the king of Israel.
verse.note: The Minor Prophets are composed of twelve books, from Hosea to Malachi. In ancient times these books might have been considered one book. "The book of the prophets" mentioned by Stephen in [link]Acts 7:42[/link], in his quoting of [link]Amos 5:25-27[/link], might refer to this collective book. These twelve books complete the divine revelation concerning God's economy in His dealings with His elect (Israel) and the nations, which is covered in detail in the books of the Major Prophets — Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, and Daniel. All the books of both the Major Prophets and the Minor Prophets were called by the Lord Jesus "the Prophets," in which things were written concerning Him ([link]Luke 24:44[/link]). Thus, the central point of all the Prophets is Christ (cf. [link]Luke 24:27[/link]; [link]John 5:39[/link]).[br/][br/]Like the Major Prophets, the Minor Prophets unveil that God's economy in His loving chastisement of Israel, in His governmental dealing with Israel, and in His judgment upon the nations issues in the manifestation of Christ as the centrality and universality in God's economy to bring in the kingdom, the age of restoration ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]; [link]Acts 3:21[/link]), which will usher the old and ruined universe into the new heaven and new earth with the New Jerusalem ([link]Rev. 21:1-2[/link]).

Meaning salvation, or deliverance (cf. [link]Num. 13:16[/link]). The object of Hosea's ministry was the adulterous and apostate kingdom of Israel. As to Israel's condition, they were adulterous; as to their position, they were apostate. This book reveals that regardless of how adulterous Israel is as the wife to Jehovah and how apostate Israel is as the people to Him, He still desires that she would return to Him. If she would return to Him, He would still receive her, bring her back, and restore her.

verse.text: At the beginning of Jehovah's speaking to Hosea, Jehovah said to Hosea,[br/]Go, take to yourself a [note]1[/note]wife of [note]2[/note]harlotries / And children of harlotries, / For the land is entirely given over to [xref]a[/xref]harlotry, / [i]And thus departs[/i] from Jehovah.
verse.note: The crucial emphasis of the revelation released by all the prophets from Isaiah to Malachi is that God wants to have an organic union with His chosen people. In this union God is His people's life and they are His expression. In this way God and His chosen people become a universal couple ([link]Rev. 22:17[/link] and note 1, par. 2). Because this is God's intention in His eternal economy, both the Major Prophets and the Minor Prophets speak of God as the Husband and of God's chosen people as the wife. This thought is fully developed in the New Testament. See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup], par. 2, in Exo. 20[/link].

The prophet Hosea took Gomer, a wife of harlotries ([link]vv. 2-3[/link]). This symbolized that God took Israel as His wife, one who gave herself to harlotries and who departed from Jehovah. God told Hosea to do what He Himself had done, and Hosea did what God commanded him.

verse.text: So he went and took Gomer the daughter of Diblaim. And she conceived and bore him a son.

And Jehovah said to him,[br/]Call his name [note]1[/note]Jezreel, / For yet a little while / And I will [note]2[/note]avenge the [xref]a[/xref]bloodshed of Jezreel / Upon the house of Jehu / And will bring an [xref]b[/xref]end to the kingdom of the house of Israel.
verse.note: Symbolizing that God would avenge the bloodshed at Jezreel ([link]2 Kings 10:1-11[/link]) upon the house of Jehu and would bring an end to the kingdom of the house of Israel ([link]2 Kings 15:10-12[/link]).
Or, visit (i.e., in order to avenge).

verse.text: And in that day / I will break the [xref]a[/xref]bow of Israel / In the valley of Jezreel.

And she conceived again and bore a daughter. And He said to him,[br/]Call her name [note]1[/note]Lo-ruhamah, / For I will no longer have compassion / On the [xref]a[/xref]house of Israel, / That I should forgive them at all.
verse.note: Meaning she has not obtained compassion and symbolizing that God would no longer have compassion on the house of Israel.

verse.text: But on the [xref]a[/xref]house of Judah I will have compassion and will save them by Jehovah their God, and I will not save them by bow or by sword or by battle, by horses or by horsemen.
When she had weaned Lo-ruhamah, she conceived and bore a son.
And He said,[br/]Call his name [note]1[/note]Lo-ammi, / For you are [xref]a[/xref]not My people, / And I will not belong to you.
verse.note: Meaning not My people and symbolizing that Israel was not God's people and God would not belong to her.

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note]number of the children of Israel will be like the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]sand of the sea, / Which cannot be measured or numbered; / [xref]b[/xref]And in the place where it will be said to them, You are not My people, / It will be said to them, [i]You are[/i] the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]sons of the living God.
verse.note: The word in [link]1:10-2:1[/link] is God's promise of restoration to the children of Israel. This promise is a matter of grace. Grace follows sin. Where sin abounds, grace abounds even more ([link]Rom. 5:20[/link]).
See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 22[/link].

Sons of the living God indicates regeneration. When God fulfills His new covenant with Israel ([link]Jer. 31:31-34[/link] and note [link]31[sup]1[/sup][/link]), He will regenerate them, putting Himself into them as their life to make them the sons of God. Thus, Israel will be not merely the people of God but also the sons of God.
verse.xref: 2 Cor. 6:18; Rev. 21:7; cf. Matt. 16:16; John 1:12; 1 John 3:1

verse.text: And the children of Judah and the children of Israel will be [xref]a[/xref]gathered together, / And they will appoint for themselves one head, and they will go up from the land, / For great will be the day of [note]1[/note]Jezreel.
verse.note: Meaning God sows, or God will sow. The day of Jezreel is the day for the people of Israel to be sown in the Holy Land by God ([link]v. 11[/link]; [link]2:22-23[/link]). Today God has sown the children of Israel back in their fathers' land, and no one can pluck them out again.

verse.text: Say to your brothers, [note]1[/note]Ammi, / And to your sisters, [note]2[/note]Ruhamah.
verse.note: Meaning My people.

Meaning she has obtained compassion. The two names in this verse indicate that ultimately Israel will be perfected by God. Under the victory of God's love, Israel will become God's people and obtain His compassion. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

verse.text: Contend with your [xref]a[/xref]mother; contend. / For she is [note]1[/note]not my wife, / And I am [note]1[/note]not her husband. / And let her turn away her [xref]b[/xref]harlotries from her face, / And her adulteries from between her breasts,
verse.note: The harlotries of Gomer, the wife of the prophet Hosea, symbolize the adulteries of Israel as the unchaste wife of Jehovah ([link]vv. 2-13[/link]). In a sense, God divorced Israel, but He did this with the strong intention of receiving her back again.

verse.text: Lest I strip her naked / And set her out as in the day she was [xref]a[/xref]born / And make her a wilderness / And make her a dry land / And slay her with thirst.
And on her children I will not have compassion, / For they are the children of harlotries.

For their mother has gone about as a [xref]a[/xref]harlot; / She who conceived them has acted shamefully; / For she has said, / I will go after my [note]1[/note]lovers, / Who give [i]me[/i] my bread and my water, / My wool and my flax, / My oil and my drink.
verse.note: Israel's lovers were her idols.

verse.text: Therefore I will now hedge up / [note]1[/note]Her way with thorns; / And I will build up a wall against her, / So that she will not find her paths.
verse.note: Following the Septuagint; the Hebrew text reads, your.

verse.text: And she will pursue her lovers / But will not overtake them; / And she will seek them but not find [i]them;[/i] / And she will say, [note]1[/note]I will go / And [xref]a[/xref]return to my first [xref]b[/xref]husband, / For it was better for me then than now.
verse.note: This indicates that although Israel would stubbornly pursue her lovers (her idols), eventually she would return to God as her first Husband.

verse.text: For she [xref]a[/xref]did not know / That it was I who gave her / The grain and the new wine and the fresh oil, / And who multiplied to her silver / And gold, which they [note]1[/note]used for Baal.
verse.note: Or, made into Baal.

verse.text: Therefore I will take back / My grain in its time / And My new wine in its appointed season, / And I will snatch away My wool and My flax, / [i]Which were[/i] to cover her nakedness.
And now I will uncover her lewdness / In the sight of her lovers, / And no one will deliver her from My hand.
And I will bring all her mirth to an end, / Her [xref]a[/xref]feasts, her new moons, and her Sabbaths, / And all her appointed assemblies.

And I will desolate her vine and her fig tree, / Of which she said, / These are my payments / That my lovers have given me; / And I will make them a forest, / And the beasts of the field will devour them.

And I will visit the days of the Baals upon her, / In which she burned incense to them / And adorned herself with her nose rings and her jewels / And went after her lovers / And forgot Me, / Declares Jehovah.
Therefore I am now luring her, / And I will bring her into the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness / And will [xref]b[/xref]speak to her heart.

And I will give her her vineyards from there / And the valley of [xref]a[/xref]Achor as a door of hope; / And she will respond there as in the days of her [xref]b[/xref]youth / And as in the day when she came up out of the land of Egypt.
And in that day, declares Jehovah, / You will call [i]Me[/i] My [xref]a[/xref]Husband / And will no longer call Me [note]1[/note]Baali.
verse.note: Meaning my Master. Also the name of a Canaanite god.

verse.text: For I will take away the names of the Baals from her mouth, / And they will no longer be remembered by their name.

And I will make a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]covenant for them / In that day / With the beasts of the field / And with the birds of heaven / And the creeping things of the earth; / And bow and sword and battle / I will [xref]b[/xref]break from the land, / And I will cause them to lie down in [xref]c[/xref]safety.
verse.note: Just as God made a covenant for us with the living things at Noah's time ([link]Gen. 9:8-11[/link]), so He will make such a covenant for Israel at the time of restoration. Because of this latter covenant, the beasts, the birds, and the creeping things will be in a good order. Also, God will break bow, sword, and battle from the land and will cause Israel to lie down in safety.

verse.text: And I will [xref]a[/xref]betroth you to Myself forever; / Indeed I will betroth you to Myself / In righteousness and justice / And in lovingkindness and compassions;
Indeed I will betroth you to Myself in faithfulness, / And you will know Jehovah.
And in that day / I will answer, declares Jehovah; / I will answer the heavens, / And they will answer the earth,
And the earth will answer the [note]1[/note]grain / And the [note]1[/note]new wine and the [note]1[/note]fresh oil, / And they will answer Jezreel.
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link] and notes [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Isa. 30[/link] and [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in Joel 3[/link].

verse.text: And I will sow her for Myself in the land; / And I will have compassion on [note]1[/note]Lo-ruhamah, / And I will say to [note]2[/note]Lo-ammi, [xref]a[/xref]You are My people; / And they will say, My God.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Then Jehovah said to me, Go [note]1[/note]again, love a woman who is loved by her companion yet who is an adulteress, even as Jehovah has [xref]a[/xref]loved the children of Israel, though they turn to other gods and love raisin cakes.
verse.note: Jehovah told Hosea to love Gomer, a woman of adulteries, again, symbolizing that Jehovah will love the children of Israel again, though they have turned to other gods (other lovers) and loved raisin cakes (pleasures for self). What Hosea did in obedience to God's command regarding Gomer was a confirmation of what God promised to do regarding Israel.

verse.text: So I bought her for myself for fifteen pieces of silver and a homer of barley and a half-homer of barley.
And I said to her, You will abide for me for [note]1[/note]many days; you shall not go about as a harlot nor be [i]another[/i] man's; and I will be the same toward you.
verse.note: Gomer's abiding with Hosea many days without going about as a harlot nor being another man's symbolizes that the children of Israel would abide for many days without king, without prince, without sacrifice, without pillar (for worship), and without ephod and teraphim (idols in homes) ([link]v. 4[/link]). These "many days" began when the Babylonians burned the temple ([link]2 Chron. 36:19[/link]). From that time Israel has been without king and without prince; furthermore, from that time until the present the Jews have not worshipped idols.

verse.text: For the children of Israel will [xref]a[/xref]abide for many days without king and without prince and without sacrifice and without pillar and without ephod and teraphim.

Afterward the children of Israel will return and [xref]a[/xref]seek Jehovah their God and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]David their King, and they will come with fear to Jehovah and to His goodness in the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]last days.
verse.note: This is Christ in the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:6b[/link]). See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in Amos 9[/link].
I.e., in the age of restoration ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]).

verse.text: Hear the word of Jehovah, / O children of Israel; / For Jehovah has a [xref]a[/xref]controversy / With the inhabitants of the land. / For there is no [note]1[/note]faithfulness or kindness / And [xref]b[/xref]no knowledge of God in the land.
verse.note: Or, truth. As the unchaste wife of Jehovah, Israel became evil. Once a wife becomes unchaste, all kinds of evils follow. Once we forsake God, we too can do any kind of evil.

verse.text: [i]Rather[/i] there are swearing and deceiving and murder / And stealing and adultery; / They are violent, / And bloodshed follows bloodshed.
Because of this the land mourns, / And all the inhabitants languish within it, / With the beasts of the field / And with the birds of heaven; / Indeed, even the fish of the sea will be taken away.
Yet let no man contend, / And let no man reprove; / For your people are like those who contend with the priest.
And [note]1[/note]you will stumble in the day, / And the prophet also will stumble / With you in the night; / And I will destroy your mother.
verse.note: Referring to the priest ([link]v. 6[/link]).

verse.text: My people are destroyed / Because of a [xref]a[/xref]lack of [note]1[/note]that knowledge. / For you have rejected [note]1[/note]that knowledge, / And I will reject you, so that you will not be a priest to Me; / Since you have forgotten the law of your God, / I also will forget your children.
verse.note: Referring back to [link]v. 1[/link].

verse.text: The more [note]1[/note]they were multiplied, the more they sinned against Me; / I will change their glory into [xref]a[/xref]shame.
verse.note: Referring again to the priests.

verse.text: They feed on the sin of My people, / And [note]1[/note]their soul desires their iniquity.
verse.note: The priests desired that the people would sin, because the more the people sinned, the more sin offerings there would be for the priests to eat.

verse.text: And it will be that as it is with the people, [note]1[/note]so it will be with the priest; / Thus I will visit their ways upon them, / And I will recompense their doings to them.
verse.note: The priests, who had been sanctified, separated, to be a special group among the people, made themselves the same as the people, becoming low and common.

verse.text: And they will eat but will [xref]a[/xref]not be filled; / And they will commit fornication but will not increase; / For they have ceased giving heed to Jehovah.
Fornication and wine / And new wine [note]1[/note]take away [i]their[/i] heart.
verse.note: The people of Israel had no heart for anything but fornication, wine, and new wine.

verse.text: My people inquire at their [note]1[/note]wooden post, / And their rod informs them of [i]things;[/i] / For a spirit of harlotries makes [i]them[/i] err, / And they have gone about as [xref]a[/xref]harlots away from their God.
verse.note: Instead of praying to God and inquiring of Him, God's people inquired at their wooden post (idol).

verse.text: Upon the tops of the mountains they offer sacrifices, / And upon the hills they burn incense, / Under oak, poplar, and terebinth, / Because its shade is good. / Therefore your daughters go about as harlots, / And your brides commit adultery.

I will not [note]1[/note]punish your daughters when they go about as harlots / Nor your brides when they commit adultery; / For [i]the men[/i] themselves go off with harlots, / And they offer sacrifices with the [note]2[/note]prostitutes; / And the people who have no understanding will be cast down.
verse.note: Or, visit (i.e., for punishment). So throughout the book.
Technically, cult prostitutes (cf. [link]Deut. 23:17[/link]).

verse.text: Though you, Israel, go about as a harlot, / Let not Judah trespass; / And do not come to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Gilgal, / Nor go up to [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Beth-aven, / Nor swear, As Jehovah lives.
verse.note: Gilgal was the center of idolatry ([link]9:15[/link]; [link]12:11[/link]; [link]Amos 4:4[/link]; [link]5:5[/link]).

Meaning house of nothingness, or house of idolatry. It was probably applied contemptuously to Bethel, which had become a seat of idolatry ([link]1 Kings 12:26-33[/link]; cf. [link]Hosea 5:8[/link]; [link]10:5[/link]).

verse.text: For Israel is [xref]a[/xref]stubborn, / Like a stubborn heifer; / Will Jehovah now pasture them / Like a lamb in a spacious place?
Ephraim is joined to idols; / Leave him alone.
Their liquor has ended; / They have given themselves up to harlotry; / Their [note]1[/note]rulers dearly love shame.
verse.note: Lit., shields.

verse.text: The wind has wrapped her up in its wings, / And they will be ashamed because of their sacrifices.
Hear this, O priests; / And listen, O house of Israel; / And, O house of the king, give ear. / For to you belongs the judgment, / For you have been a snare at Mizpah / And a net spread over Tabor.
And the revolters have gone deep [note]1[/note]into slaughtering, / Though I am a chastisement to them all.
verse.note: Others read, in corruption.

verse.text: I know Ephraim, / And Israel is not hidden from Me; / For now, Ephraim, you have gone about as a [xref]a[/xref]harlot; / Israel is defiled.
Their doings do not permit them / To turn to their God; / For a spirit of harlotries is within them, / And they do not know Jehovah.
And the pride of Israel testifies to his face, / And Ephraim and Israel will stumble in their iniquity; / Judah also will stumble with them.
With their flocks and with their herds they will go / To [xref]a[/xref]seek Jehovah, / But they will not find Him; / He has withdrawn Himself from them.
They have acted treacherously against Jehovah, / For they have begotten strange children. / Now the new moon will devour them / With their apportionments.
Blow the horn in Gibeah, / The trumpet in Ramah; / Sound an alarm at [xref]a[/xref]Beth-aven: / Behind you, O Benjamin!
Ephraim will be a desolation / In the day of correction; / Among the tribes of Israel / I have made known what is sure.
The princes of Judah have become / Like those who move a [xref]a[/xref]boundary mark. / I will pour out upon them / My overflowing wrath like water.
Ephraim is oppressed, / Crushed by judgment, / For he was determined to walk / After [i]man's[/i] command.
Therefore I am like a moth to Ephraim / And like rottenness to the house of Judah.

When Ephraim saw his sickness, / And Judah his [xref]a[/xref]wound, / Ephraim went to [xref]b[/xref]Assyria / And sent [i]word[/i] to the warrior king; / But he cannot heal you, / And the wound will not depart from you.

For I will be like a lion to Ephraim / And like a young lion to the house of Judah. / I, I will tear [i]them[/i] and go away; / I will carry [i]them[/i] off, and there will be no one to deliver [i]them.[/i]
I will go away, I will return to My place, / [xref]a[/xref]Until they acknowledge their offense / And seek My face; / In their affliction they will seek Me [note]1[/note]earnestly.
verse.note: Eventually, in their affliction Israel will seek God earnestly. Thus, the divine chastisement of Israel will be effective.

verse.text: Come and let us [xref]a[/xref]return to Jehovah; / For He has torn [i]us,[/i] but He will [xref]b[/xref]heal us, / And He has stricken [i]us,[/i] but He will bind us up.
He will enliven us after [note]1[/note]two days; / On the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]third day He will raise us up, / And we will live in His presence.
verse.note: With the Lord one day is like a thousand years ([link]2 Pet. 3:8[/link]). According to this principle, the two days here may signify the first two periods of a thousand years each, counting from A.D. 70, when the Roman prince Titus destroyed Jerusalem and the temple, cruelly killed thousands of Jews, and scattered the Jews among the nations. From that time the Jews have been without king, without prince, without sacrifice, and without the temple, fulfilling Hosea's prophecy in [link]3:4[/link]. For two thousand years God has left Israel in a dead condition. After this two thousand-year period, the third thousand years will come. The third day may signify a third period of a thousand years, that is, the millennium, the age of restoration, which will be in the reality of Christ's resurrection ([link]Rev. 20:6[/link]). At that time Israel will be raised up, that is, restored.[br/][br/]Christ was resurrected on the third day ([link]1 Cor. 15:4[/link]), and as the pneumatic Christ, the life-giving Spirit, in resurrection ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), He is the reality of the third day ([link]John 11:25[/link]). Whenever we contact such a Christ, we are brought from the desolation of the two days to the resurrection of the third day. Cf. note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Hab. 3[/link].

verse.text: Therefore let us know, let us pursue knowing Jehovah: / [note]1[/note]His going forth is as sure as the [xref]a[/xref]dawn, / And He will come to us as the rain, / As the late rain which [xref]b[/xref]waters the earth.
verse.note: In His second coming Christ will go forth as the dawn and come to Israel as the late rain that waters the earth. At that time, in the restoration, the millennium ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]), the people of Israel will be the earth watered by Christ as the late rain (cf. [link]Psa. 72:6[/link] and note). See notes [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Micah 5[/link] and [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Joel 2[/link].

verse.text: What shall I do with you, O [note]1[/note]Ephraim? / What shall I do with you, O Judah? / For your lovingkindness is like a morning cloud / And like dew that departs early.
verse.note: Another term for the northern kingdom of Israel. So also throughout the book.

verse.text: Therefore I hewed [i]them[/i] to pieces by the prophets; / I slew them by the [xref]a[/xref]words of My mouth, / And [note]1[/note]My judgments went forth as light.
verse.note: According to the Septuagint; the Hebrew text reads, the judgments on you were light that went forth.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]For I delight in lovingkindness and not [xref]b[/xref]sacrifice, / And the knowledge of God more than burnt offerings.
But they like Adam have transgressed the covenant; / There they have acted treacherously against Me.
Gilead is a city of those who commit iniquity; / It is tracked with blood.
And like bands of robbers lying in wait for a man, / The company of priests murder on the way to Shechem; / Indeed they commit wickedness.
In the house of Israel I have seen a horrid thing: / The harlotry of Ephraim is there; / Israel has defiled itself.
Also, O Judah, there is a [note]1[/note]harvest appointed for you, / When I will [xref]a[/xref]turn the captivity of My people.
verse.note: In the restoration all the Israelites, including the northern kingdom of Israel and the southern kingdom of Judah, will be very rich in all kinds of produce from the earth. The earth was created by God to produce a rich harvest, but because of the fall of man the earth was cursed to grow thorns, and man has had to labor with sweat for food ([link]Gen. 3:17-19[/link]). In the restoration the earth will be restored to its original condition and will be rich, fertile, and productive. Thus, a harvest will be apportioned to Judah for their enjoyment. See notes [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Isa. 30[/link] and [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in Joel 3[/link].

verse.text: When I would [xref]a[/xref]heal Israel, / Then the [note]1[/note]iniquity of Ephraim is discovered / As well as the evil deeds of Samaria; / For they practice falsehood. / And the thief comes inside; / The band of robbers makes raids outside.
verse.note: The sins of Israel were in two categories: sins in their social life among the people and the rulers ([link]vv. 1-7[/link]) and evils in their relationship with Jehovah ([link]vv. 8-16[/link]). Israel was wrong with man and also with God.

verse.text: And they do not say in their hearts / That I [xref]a[/xref]remember all their evil. / Now their doings are all around them; / They are before My [xref]b[/xref]face.
They make the king glad with their evil, / And the princes, with their lies.
All of them practice adultery; / They are like an oven heated by the baker: / He ceases from stirring [i]the fire,[/i] / After kneading the dough, until it is [xref]a[/xref]leavened.
On the [i]feast[/i] day of our king / The princes made themselves sick with the heat of wine; / He stretched out his hand with scorners.
For they have made their heart ready / Like an oven while they lie in wait: / All night long / Their baker sleeps, / [i]But[/i] in the morning [note]1[/note]the oven burns / Like a flaming fire.
verse.note: Lit., it.

verse.text: All of them are hot like an oven, / And they devour their [note]1[/note]judges; / All their kings fall; / There is no one among them who [xref]a[/xref]calls on Me.
verse.note: I.e., the priests.

verse.text: Ephraim — among the peoples / He mixes himself; / Ephraim is a cake / [note]1[/note]Not turned.
verse.note: This symbolizes that Israel was stubborn, remaining in a "charcoaled" condition and being unwilling to turn to Jehovah.

verse.text: Strangers have devoured his strength, / And he himself does not know [i]it;[/i] / Indeed gray hairs are all over him, / And he himself does not know [i]it.[/i]
And the pride of Israel testifies to his face; / Yet they have not returned to Jehovah their God, / And they have not sought [i]Him,[/i] because of all this.
And Ephraim has become like a silly dove / Without [note]1[/note]understanding: / They call to [xref]a[/xref]Egypt; / They go to Assyria.
verse.note: Israel's being likened to a silly dove symbolizes that they were lacking the proper knowledge of God in His economy.

verse.text: When they go, / I will spread My net over them; / I will bring them down like the birds of heaven; / I will chasten them according to the report [i]given[/i] to their assembly.
Woe to them! For they have wandered from Me. / Devastation to them! For they have transgressed against Me. / And I would have redeemed them, / But they have spoken lies against Me.
And they did not cry unto Me in their heart / When they howled in their beds. / For grain and new wine they assemble themselves; / They rebel against Me.
Though I trained [i]them and[/i] strengthened their arms, / They devise evil against Me.

They return, [i]but[/i] not to [i]Him who is[/i] on high; / They are like a [note]1[/note]deceitful bow. / Their princes will fall by the sword / Because of the rage of their tongue. / This will be their derision / In the land of [xref]a[/xref]Egypt.
verse.note: Israel's being likened to a deceitful bow symbolizes that they were rebellious toward God and were not faithful to fight the battle for God's kingdom.

verse.text: A trumpet to your lips! / Like an [xref]a[/xref]eagle [i]he comes[/i] against the house of Jehovah, / Because they have trespassed My [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]covenant / And have transgressed against My [note]1[/note]law.
verse.note: Jehovah's covenant is His binding of Israel in His holy requirements and righteous terms, and Jehovah's law is His regulating of Israel according to what He is: love, light, holiness, and righteousness (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 20[/link]).

verse.text: They will cry unto Me, / My God, we — Israel — know You.
Israel has cast off what is good; / The enemy will pursue him.

They have set up [xref]a[/xref]kings, but not by Me; / They have set up princes, but I did not acknowledge [i]it.[/i] / With their silver and their gold they made / Idols for themselves, / That they might be cut off.
Your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]calf has cast [i]you[/i] off, O [note]1[/note]Samaria; / My anger burns against them. / How long will they be incapable of [note]2[/note]innocence?
verse.note: Samaria was a capital of the northern kingdom of Israel ([link]1 Kings 16:29[/link]), and her calf was an idol ([link]v. 6[/link]), a golden calf image (cf. [link]1 Kings 12:28[/link]; [link]Exo. 32:4[/link]).
Here innocence means not making idols.

verse.text: For from Israel is this! / A workman made it; / Thus it is no God. / The calf of Samaria / Will be [i]shattered to[/i] pieces.

For they have [xref]a[/xref]sown wind, / And they will reap a whirlwind. / It has no stalk; [i]should there be[/i] a sprout, / It will not produce flour; / If it should produce, / Strangers will swallow it up.
Israel has been swallowed up; / Now they have become among the nations / Like a vessel in which no one takes pleasure.
For they have gone up to [xref]a[/xref]Assyria / [i]Like[/i] a wild ass gone alone by itself; / Ephraim has [xref]b[/xref]hired lovers.

Indeed though they have hired [i]such[/i] among the nations, / I will now [xref]a[/xref]gather them; / And they will begin to be diminished because of the burden / Of the [xref]b[/xref]king of the princes.
Because Ephraim has multiplied altars for sin, / Altars will be to him for sin.
I wrote for him the ten thousand things of My law, / [i]But[/i] they are considered as a strange thing.

As for the sacrifices of My offerings, / They sacrifice flesh and eat [i]it,[/i] / [i]But[/i] Jehovah has [xref]a[/xref]no delight in them. / Now He will [xref]b[/xref]remember their iniquity, / And He will punish their sins; / They will return to [xref]c[/xref]Egypt.

For Israel has forgotten his [xref]a[/xref]Maker / And has built palaces, / And Judah has multiplied fortified cities; / But I will send [note]1[/note]fire into his cities, / And it will devour its citadels.
verse.note: The minor prophets spoke concerning the evils, the rottenness, and the corruption of Israel, but Israel was stubborn and would not listen to them. Eventually, God was forced to send the Assyrians and the Babylonians as the fire to judge, to punish, and to chastise His rebellious and apostate people.

verse.text: Do not rejoice, O Israel, / To exult like the nations. / For you have gone as a [xref]a[/xref]harlot away from your God; / You have loved payment / Upon every grain floor.
The threshing floor and the winepress will not feed them, / And the new wine will fail her.
They will not dwell in the land of Jehovah; / But Ephraim will return to [xref]a[/xref]Egypt, / And in Assyria they will eat [xref]b[/xref]what is unclean.

They will not pour out offerings of wine to Jehovah, / Neither will their sacrifices be pleasing to Him; / They will be to them as the bread of mourning; / All who eat them will be unclean, / For their bread will be for themselves; / It will not come into the house of Jehovah.
What will you do / In the day of assembly / And in the day of the feast of Jehovah?

For they will go because of destruction; / Egypt will gather them; / [note]1[/note]Moph will bury them. / As for their desirable [note]2[/note]things of silver, nettles will dispossess them; / Thistles will be in their tents.
verse.note: Probably Memphis, an Egyptian city near the Nile; elsewhere called Noph.
Idols made of silver.

verse.text: The days of the visitation have come; / The days of the recompense have come; / Israel will know [i]it.[/i] / The prophet is a fool, / The [note]1[/note]inspired man is mad, / Because of the greatness of your iniquity / And [i]because of[/i] the greatness of the enmity.
verse.note: Lit., man of the spirit. Israel's considering a prophet as a fool and considering a man of the spirit, an inspired one, as mad indicates that they did not care for God's interests. On the contrary, they thought that caring for God's interests was foolishness.

verse.text: Ephraim was a [note]1[/note]watchman / With my God. / As for the [note]2[/note]prophet, a fowler's trap / Is in all his ways; / Enmity is in the house of his God.
verse.note: This indicates that in the past the northern kingdom of Israel was quite good.
This may mean that the prophets had become so evil that wherever they went they were a trap to snare the people. In the temple the prophets created enmity; they did not have love or sympathy.

verse.text: They have deeply corrupted themselves / As in the days of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Gibeah; / He will remember their iniquity; / He will punish their sins.
verse.note: The corruption of Israel was so great that it matched the corruption in the days of Gibeah as described in [link]Judges 19:15-30[/link].

verse.text: I [note]1[/note]found Israel / Like grapes in the wilderness; / I saw your fathers / As the first ripe fruit on the fig tree at its beginning. / They went to [xref]a[/xref]Baal-peor / And sanctified themselves unto the shameful thing, / And they became detestable, like the thing that they loved.
verse.note: This refers to the time of the exodus from Egypt, when God considered Israel a young wife ([link]Jer. 2:2[/link]). However, when this wife grew up, she left God for Baal and went to Baal-peor (a city named after the idol Baal of Peor — [link]Num. 25:3[/link]; [link]Psa. 106:28[/link]) and sanctified herself unto the shameful thing (idol) and became an abomination, like the thing (idol) that she loved.

verse.text: As for Ephraim, their glory / Will fly away like a bird — / No birth, no pregnancy, and no conception!
For even if they bring up their children, / I will bereave them, [i]so that[/i] not a man [i]is left.[/i] / Indeed woe also to them / When I [xref]a[/xref]turn away from them.
Ephraim, as I have seen [i]him,[/i] / Is planted like Tyre in a meadow; / But Ephraim will bring forth / His children to the slayer.
Give them, O Jehovah — / What will You give [i]them?[/i] / Give them a miscarrying womb / And dry breasts.

All their evil is in [xref]a[/xref]Gilgal, / For there I hated them. / Because of the evil of their doings / I will drive them from My house, / I will love them no more; / All their princes are rebels.
Ephraim is stricken; / Their root is dried up; / They will not bear fruit. / Indeed though they bring forth, / I will kill the beloved [i]fruit[/i] of their womb.
My God has rejected them, / For they did not listen to Him. / And they will be [xref]a[/xref]wanderers among the nations.

Israel is a luxuriant [xref]a[/xref]vine; / He brings forth fruit for [note]1[/note]himself. / According to the abundance of his fruit / He has multiplied altars; / According to the goodness of their land / They have made pillars well.
verse.note: The fruit of the vine should have been offered to God as a drink offering (see note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in Lev. 23[/link]), but Israel used the vines to bring forth fruit for themselves, not for God. They became rich, but they used their produce to build up altars and to make idols.

verse.text: Their heart is [xref]a[/xref]divided; / Now they will be found guilty. / He Himself will break down their altars; / He will destroy their pillars.
For now they will say, / We have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]no king, / For we did not fear Jehovah; / And the king, what can he do for us?
verse.note: Because they did not fear Jehovah, Israel was not able to be in a proper situation, with God's deputy authority (a king) among them. This refers to the headship, the leadership, representing God as His authority among His people.

verse.text: They speak [i]mere[/i] words, / Swearing falsely / While making a covenant; / And judgment sprouts forth like poisonous weeds / In the furrows of the field.

The inhabitants of Samaria will fear / For the [xref]a[/xref]calves of [note]1[/note]Beth-aven; / For its people will mourn over it, / And its idol priests [note]2[/note]will tremble for it, / For its glory, / Because it has departed from it.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].
Others translate, who rejoiced over it.

verse.text: Indeed it will be carried to [xref]a[/xref]Assyria: / A present to the warrior king. / Ephraim will be taken in shame, / And Israel will be ashamed of his own counsel.
[xref]a[/xref]Samaria will be cut off [i]with[/i] her king / [i]And will be[/i] like twigs on the surface of the water.

And the high places of Aven, the sin of Israel, / Will be destroyed. / The thorn and the thistle will come up / Upon their altars; / And they will say to the [xref]a[/xref]mountains, Cover us! / And to the hills, Fall on us!
Since the days of [xref]a[/xref]Gibeah / You have sinned, O Israel; / There they have stood. / Did not the [xref]b[/xref]battle / Overtake them in Gibeah / Because of the children of iniquity?
When I so desire, I will chastise them; / And the peoples will be [xref]a[/xref]gathered against them, / When they are bound for their [note]1[/note]double iniquity.
verse.note: Referring to Israel's two evils in forsaking Jehovah and turning to idols ([link]Jer. 2:13[/link] and note).

verse.text: And Ephraim is a trained heifer / That loves to tread [i]the grain;[/i] / But I have passed [i]the yoke[/i] / Over her fair neck: / I will make Ephraim draw [i]the plow;[/i] / Judah will plow; / Jacob will break his clods.

[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sow unto righteousness for yourselves; / Reap according to lovingkindness; / Break up your [note]2[/note]fallow ground; / For it is time to seek Jehovah / Until He comes and rains / Righteousness on you.
verse.note: Here to sow means to seek Jehovah. To seek Jehovah rightly is to sow rightly. Thus, Hosea charged the children of Israel to sow unto righteousness. If they did this, they would reap according to lovingkindness. Otherwise, if they plowed wickedness, they would reap injustice. Cf. [link]Gal. 6:7-8[/link].

Fallow ground is ground that has been plowed but has not been sown. The children of Israel were the fallow ground. They had been plowed by God but had not been sown with righteousness. They were to break up the fallow ground; i.e., they were to seek God until Christ came as righteousness to rain righteousness upon them.

verse.text: You have plowed wickedness; / You have reaped injustice; / You have eaten the fruit of lying. / For you have trusted in your way, / In the multitude of your mighty men.

And a [note]1[/note]tumult will arise among your peoples; / And all your fortresses will be devastated, / As [xref]a[/xref]Shalman devastated Beth-arbel / In the day of battle: / The mother was dashed in pieces with the children.
verse.note: Hosea's prophecy in [link]vv. 14-15[/link] was fully fulfilled by Titus and his Roman army in A.D. 70.

verse.text: Thus Bethel will cause this to happen to you / Because of your great evil: / At [note]1[/note]dawn the king of Israel / Will be utterly cut off.
verse.note: This word indicates that Israel was in the night, in darkness. They were a people who were altogether lacking in righteousness and justice. They forsook God and they were evil to one another.

verse.text: When Israel was a [xref]a[/xref]child, I [note]1[/note]loved him, / And [xref]b[/xref]out of Egypt I called My [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]son.
verse.note: The last four chapters of this book concern Jehovah's unchanging love versus Israel's stubborn unchastity. Israel is depicted as the wife of Jehovah throughout this book ([link]2:7[/link], [link]19[/link]). But when God's everlasting and unchanging love is touched, Israel is called God's son ([link]Exo. 4:22-23[/link]), indicating that in God's view Israel has the Father's life (cf. [link]1:10[/link] and note 3). God's everlasting love is not a love in affection, like the love of a husband toward a wife, but a love in life, like the love of a father toward a son. On the one hand, God loves us as His wife, and the Lord Jesus is our Husband ([link]John 3:29[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 11:2[/link]). On the other hand, God is our Father, and we are sons of the Father ([link]Gal. 3:26[/link]; [link]4:6[/link]).[br/][br/]Although God is loving, He is also a God of purity and righteousness. He cannot tolerate any kind of uncleanness or unrighteousness. Wherever these things are found among God's people, God comes in to chastise them. Nevertheless, when God's people are chastised by Him, they are still loved by Him (cf. [link]Heb. 12:6[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:19[/link]). God's everlasting love ([link]Jer. 31:3[/link]) is always victorious. Eventually, in spite of our failures and mistakes, God's love will gain the victory (cf. [link]Rom. 8:35-39[/link]).

Implying Christ in His union with Israel as the Son of God, who is loved by God and was called out of Egypt by God ([link]Matt. 2:13-15[/link]). This indicates that although Israel became exceedingly evil, Christ still became organically one with Israel through incarnation to be a real Israelite. Christ joined Himself to Israel in the matter of being a son of God.[br/][br/]This verse implies Christ as the Son of God. It also implies that all God's chosen people become sons of God by virtue of their being organically united with Christ (cf. [link]Rom. 11:17[/link] and notes; [link]Gal. 3:26[/link] and note 2). This is possible because Christ is the Son of God in two aspects: the aspect of His being the only begotten Son of God and the aspect of His being the firstborn Son of God. In eternity Christ was God's only begotten Son ([link]John 3:16[/link]; [link]1 John 4:9[/link]), possessing only divinity without humanity. As such, He was unique. However, one day Christ was incarnated to be a man, taking on human nature and joining Himself with humanity ([link]John 1:14[/link]). After dying an all-inclusive, vicarious death on the cross, He entered into resurrection. In resurrection and through resurrection He was begotten of God in His humanity to be the firstborn Son of God, possessing both divinity and humanity ([link]Acts 13:33[/link] and note; [link]Rom. 1:3-4[/link] and notes). Hence, in addition to His being the unique, only begotten Son of God from eternity, Christ, after His incarnation and through His resurrection, has become the Son of God in another sense, in the sense of being the firstborn Son of God ([link]Heb. 1:5-6[/link]). Furthermore, in Christ's resurrection all His believers were begotten of God, regenerated ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]), to be the many sons of God ([link]Heb. 2:10[/link]), Christ's many brothers ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]), to be His members for the constituting of His organic Body. All this is implied in this verse.

verse.text: As [note]1[/note]they called them, / So they went from them; / To the [xref]a[/xref]Baals they sacrificed, / And to the idols they burned incense.
verse.note: The prophets. God sent the prophets to call Israel again and again, but the more the prophets called them, the farther they went away from the prophets. From the time Titus destroyed Jerusalem and the temple in A.D. 70 until now, God has not raised up any prophets among the Jews. According to the Lord's word in [link]Matt. 21:43[/link], the kingdom of God has been taken from the Jews and has been given to the church. In the church every regenerated believer is a priest ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:6[/link]), and every believer should endeavor to prophesy ([link]1 Cor. 14:1[/link], [link]31[/link], [link]39[/link]; cf. [link]Num. 11:29[/link]).

verse.text: And it was I who taught Ephraim to walk / (He [xref]a[/xref]took them in His arms), / But they did not know that I [xref]b[/xref]healed them.

I drew them [note]1[/note]with cords of a man, / With bands of love;[br/]And I was to them like those / Who lift off the [note]2[/note]yoke on their jaws; / And I gently caused them to [note]2[/note]eat.
verse.note: The phrase with cords of a man, with bands of love indicates that God loves us with His divine love not on the level of divinity but on the level of humanity. God's love is divine, but it reaches us in the cords of a man, i.e., through Christ's humanity. The cords through which God draws us include Christ's incarnation, human living, crucifixion, resurrection, and ascension. It is by all these steps of Christ in His humanity that God's love in His salvation reaches us ([link]Rom. 5:8[/link]; [link]1 John 4:9-10[/link]). Apart from Christ, God's everlasting love, His unchanging, subduing love, could not be prevailing in relation to us. God's unchanging love is prevailing because it is a love in Christ, with Christ, by Christ, and for Christ.

This yoke was Pharaoh's yoke in Egypt, and this eating was the eating of the manna, a type of Christ as our heavenly food ([link]John 6:31-35[/link]), in the wilderness. Pharaoh had put a strong yoke on Israel, but God took off that yoke and gently caused them to eat by bringing them into the wilderness, where God fed them with manna in a gentle way morning by morning ([link]Exo. 16:14-18[/link]).

verse.text: They will not return to the land of Egypt, / But the Assyrian will be their king, / For they refused to return [i]to Me.[/i]
And the sword will whirl about in their cities / And will consume their bars, / And it will devour [i]them[/i] because of their own counsels.
Indeed My people are bent upon turning away from Me; / Though they call them to [i]Him who is[/i] on high, / None at all exalts [i]Him.[/i]

How shall I give you up, O Ephraim? / [i]How[/i] shall I deliver you up, O Israel? / How can I make you like [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Admah? / [i]How[/i] can I treat you like [note]1[/note]Zeboim? / My heart is turned within Me; / All My [xref]b[/xref]compassions have warmed.
verse.note: Admah and Zeboim were destroyed with Sodom and Gomorrah ([link]Deut. 29:23[/link]). Israel had become even more evil than Sodom and Gomorrah. However, because of His everlasting love, God would not destroy Israel ([link]v. 9[/link]).

verse.text: I will not execute the fierceness of My anger; / I will not return to destroy Ephraim; / For I am God and [xref]a[/xref]not man, / The [xref]b[/xref]Holy One in the midst of you, / And I will not come in wrath.
They will walk after Jehovah; / He will [xref]a[/xref]roar like a lion. / For He will roar, / And the children will come trembling from the [xref]b[/xref]west.
They will come trembling like a bird from Egypt / And like a [xref]a[/xref]dove from the land of Assyria. / And I will cause them to [xref]b[/xref]dwell in their houses, / Declares Jehovah.
Ephraim encompasses Me with lies, / And the house of Israel, with deceit; / And Judah is yet unsteadfast with God / And with the Holy One, the Faithful One.
Ephraim feeds on wind / And follows the east wind continually; / He multiplies lies and violence. / They make a covenant with [xref]a[/xref]Assyria, / And oil is carried into Egypt.
Jehovah has also a [xref]a[/xref]controversy with Judah / And will punish Jacob according to his ways; / According to his doings He will recompense him.
In the womb he [xref]a[/xref]grasped his brother by the heel, / And in his full strength he contended with God.
Indeed he [xref]a[/xref]contended with the [note]1[/note]Angel and prevailed; / He wept and made supplication to Him. / At [xref]b[/xref]Bethel he found Him; / And there He spoke with us,
verse.note: The Angel with whom Jacob contended was Christ ([link]Gen. 32:24-32[/link] and notes).

verse.text: Even Jehovah the God of hosts; / Jehovah is His memorial.
And you, [xref]a[/xref]return [i]there[/i] to your God; / Keep lovingkindness and justice, / And [xref]b[/xref]wait on your God continually.
[i]He is[/i] a merchant; / In his hand are balances of deceit; / He loves to extort.
And Ephraim said, / I have surely become rich; / I have found wealth for myself. / In all my labors / They will find with me / No iniquity, which would be sin.
[xref]a[/xref]But I have been Jehovah your God / Since the land of Egypt; / Yet again I will cause you to dwell in [xref]b[/xref]tents / As in the days of the appointed feast.
I have also spoken unto the prophets: / And I have multiplied vision, / And through the prophets I have used similitudes.
Is [xref]a[/xref]Gilead iniquity? They are altogether vanity. / In [xref]b[/xref]Gilgal they sacrifice oxen; / Indeed their altars are like heaps / In the furrows of a field.
And Jacob fled into the country of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Aram; / And Israel [xref]b[/xref]served for a wife, / And for a wife he kept [i]sheep.[/i]
verse.note: I.e., Syria.

verse.text: And by a [xref]a[/xref]prophet Jehovah brought Israel up from Egypt, / And by a prophet he was kept.
Ephraim [xref]a[/xref]provoked [i]Him[/i] to bitter anger; / Therefore his Lord will leave his bloodshed upon him / And will recompense him with his own reproach.
When Ephraim spoke, there was trembling. / He exalted himself in Israel; / But he trespassed through [xref]a[/xref]Baal and died.

And now they sin more and more / And make molten images for themselves out of their silver, / Idols according to their own understanding, / All of it the work of craftsmen. / Of them they say, / Let the men who sacrifice / Kiss the calves.
Therefore they will be like a morning cloud / And like dew that departs early, / Like chaff driven by a storm wind from the threshing floor / And like smoke from a window vent.
But I have been Jehovah your God / Since the land of Egypt; / And you were to know no god except Me, / For there is no [xref]a[/xref]savior besides Me.
I knew you in the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness, / In the land of great drought.
According to their pasturage they became [xref]a[/xref]full; / They became full, and their heart was exalted; / Therefore they have [xref]b[/xref]forgotten Me.
Thus I will be to them like a [xref]a[/xref]lion; / Like a leopard I will watch [i]them[/i] along the way.
I will meet them like a bear robbed of her cubs, / And I will tear away the covering of their heart; / And I will devour them there like a lioness; / The beast of the field will tear them to pieces.
[i]It is[/i] your destruction, O Israel, / That you are against Me, against your help.
Where then is your king, / That he may save you in all your cities, / And your judges of whom you said, / [xref]a[/xref]Give me a king and some princes?
I gave you a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]king in My anger / And [xref]b[/xref]took [i]him[/i] away in My overflowing wrath.
verse.note: The king given by Jehovah in His anger might have been Saul, who was eventually taken away by Jehovah in His overflowing wrath ([link]1 Sam. 8:4-7[/link]; [link]9:17[/link]; [link]10:1[/link]; [link]31:1-13[/link]).

verse.text: The iniquity of Ephraim is bound up; / His sin is laid up in store.
The [xref]a[/xref]pains of a woman giving birth will come upon him. / He is an unwise son; / For he should not delay at the time / The children break forth.

From the power of [note]1[/note]Sheol I will ransom them; / From [xref]a[/xref]death I will redeem them. / [xref]b[/xref]Where are your plagues, O death? / Where is your destruction, O [note]1[/note]Sheol? / [note]2[/note]Repentance will be hidden from My eyes.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link].
God's love for Israel is everlasting (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link]; [link]Jer. 31:3[/link]), and He will never repent of this love (cf. [link]Rom. 11:28-29[/link]).

verse.text: Even if he should be fruitful among [i]his[/i] brothers, / An east wind will come, / A wind of Jehovah / Coming up from the wilderness, / And his spring will become dry, / And his fountain will be dried up. / He will plunder the treasure / Of every desirable vessel.
[xref]a[/xref]Samaria will be guilty, / For she rebelled against her God. / They will fall by the sword; / Their children will be dashed in pieces, / And their pregnant women will be ripped up.
[xref]a[/xref]Return, O Israel, / To Jehovah your God, / For you have fallen by your iniquity.
Take words with you, / And return to Jehovah; / Say to Him, / Forgive all iniquity, / And take [i]us[/i] graciously; / Thus we will render [note]1[/note]our [xref]a[/xref]lips [i]as[/i] bulls.
verse.note: The Septuagint translates, the fruit of our lips (cf. [link]Heb. 13:15[/link]).

verse.text: Assyria will not save us; / We will not ride upon horses. / Neither will we say again to the work of our hands, Our God! / Because in You the orphan finds compassion.
[note]1[/note]I will [xref]a[/xref]heal their apostasy; / I will love them freely; / For My anger has turned away from him.
verse.note: [link]Verses 4-8[/link] portray Israel in the restoration ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]), as revealed in [link]2:15-23[/link]; [link]3:5[/link]; [link]6:1-3[/link]; [link]10:12[/link]. Israel's transformation as described in [link]vv. 4-7[/link] is based on the factor of love in life (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link]). Love in affection does not transform, but love in life transforms people through the growth in life. Our relationship with God is of the divine, eternal life of God ([link]1 John 5:11[/link]). This life enlivens us, regenerates us, sanctifies us positionally and dispositionally, renews us, transforms us, conforms us, matures us, and glorifies us, making us the same as God in life, nature, appearance, and glory. At the beginning of this book Israel was a harlot, but at the end of this book, Israel has become a son ([link]11:1[/link]). Thus, the outcome of this book is transformation in life by God's love (cf. [link]Rom. 8:28-39[/link]; [link]Heb. 12:5-10[/link]).

verse.text: I will be like the [xref]a[/xref]dew to Israel; / He will bud like the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]lily / And will send forth his roots like [i]the[/i] [note]2[/note][i]trees of[/i] Lebanon.
verse.note: Signifying a pure life that trusts in God ([link]Matt. 6:28[/link]).
Signifying standing steadily in the uplifted humanity (cf. [link]S.S. 3:9[/link]).

verse.text: His [note]1[/note]shoots will go forth; / And his [note]2[/note]splendor will be like [i]that of[/i] the [xref]a[/xref]olive tree, / And his [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]fragrance, like [i]that of the trees of[/i] Lebanon.
verse.note: Signifying flourishing and spreading.
Signifying glory in faithfulness.
Signifying the sweet odor of a life in the uplifted humanity.

verse.text: Those who [note]1[/note]sit under his shade will return; / They will revive [i]like[/i] [note]2[/note]grain / And will [note]3[/note]bud like the vine; / His [note]4[/note]renown will be like the wine of Lebanon.
verse.note: Signifying being overshadowed by the sufficient grace enjoyed by them ([link]2 Cor. 12:9[/link]).
Signifying being full of life for producing satisfying food.
Signifying blossoming for producing cheering drink.
Signifying a good name spreading like tasteful wine.

verse.text: Ephraim [i]says,[/i] What have I yet to do with idols? / I respond and look on him. / I am like a [note]1[/note]green [xref]a[/xref]fir tree; / [note]2[/note]From Me your fruit is found.
verse.note: Symbolizing God's being living and evergreen.
Ephraim's bearing fruit from Jehovah indicates Israel's oneness with Jehovah. This is more than an organic union; it is the oneness of two in one life, in one nature, and in one living.

verse.text: Who is wise? / Then let him understand these things. / [i]Who is[/i] intelligent? Then let him know them. / For the [xref]a[/xref]ways of Jehovah are right, / And the righteous will walk in them, / But the transgressors will stumble in them.
